nodes.text: Characterize how transient soft errors propagate in DNN accelerator systems and develop cost-effective mitigation techniques that reduce silent data corruptions while incurring low area and performance overheads

Method: Perform large-scale fault-injection experiments by modifying a Tiny-CNN simulator to inject single-event transient bit-flips into datapath latches and buffer storage, mapping simulator code to hardware components

Method: Study four convolutional neural networks (ConvNet, AlexNet, CaffeNet, NiN) with pre-trained weights and datasets (CIFAR-10, ImageNet) and evaluate multiple data types (DOUBLE, FLOAT, FLOAT16, 32b_rb26, 32b_rb10, 16b_rb10)

Method: Analyze both datapath faults (PE ALU latches) and buffer faults using nine accelerators abstraction for datapath and a case study of the Eyeriss accelerator for buffer reuse and FIT projection to 16nm
Method: Define DNN-specific SDC metrics (SDC-1, SDC-5, SDC-10%, SDC-20%) and compute FIT rates using per-component size, raw FIT density, and SDC probabilities

Claim: Propose two mitigation techniques based on characterization: symptom-based detectors (software, checking activation value ranges) and selective latch hardening (hardware, protect most-sensitive bits/latches)

Result/Evidence: Conducted 3,000 random single-bit fault injections per latch/component per configuration, analyzed error propagation across bit positions, layers, values, data types, and data reuse; used 95% confidence intervals for error bars

Result: SDC sensitivity depends strongly on data type and bit position — high-order exponent bits in floating point and high integer bits in fixed-point cause most SDCs; narrower dynamic range data types reduce SDC probability

Result: Network topology and layer types affect resilience — shallower networks (ConvNet) and fully-connected layers are more SDC-sensitive; normalization layers (LRN) and pooling/ReLU mask many faults

Result: Data reuse in buffers dramatically increases SDC probability and projected FIT rates because buffer faults can be read multiple times and spread; Eyeriss case study shows some buffers can raise FIT by over 100x

Result: Datapath and buffer FIT rates vary by network and data type; datapath FITs can be non-negligible (up to ~2.45 in worst cases) and buffers often contribute orders-of-magnitude higher FITs, possibly exceeding ISO 26262 budgets without protection

Claim: Large numeric deviations in activations caused by faults are strongly correlated with SDCs; correct activation values are typically clustered in small per-layer ranges, enabling value-range based detection

Result/Evidence: Symptom-based detectors using learned per-layer activation bounds (with 10% cushion) achieve average precision ~90.21% and recall ~92.5%, and can reduce Eyeriss FIT (FLOAT) from 8.55 to 0.35 (96% reduction)

Result/Evidence: Selective Latch Hardening that prioritizes protection of most-sensitive bits yields exponential FIT reduction vs protected-latch fraction; combined use of multiple hardening primitives can achieve ~100x latch FIT reduction with ~20-25% latch-area overhead

Conclusion: By choosing just-enough data types, leveraging normalization layers, applying symptom-based detectors to buffers, and selectively hardening sensitive datapath latches, DNN accelerator SDC rates and FITs can be reduced by orders of magnitude with acceptable area and performance overheads
